page.title: 05Whitelye Stud
page.content: Another type of farming can be seen at Whitelye Stud, where they have got ten thoroughbred horses which they breed to sell and race. The horses are fed on oats every morning before they are put out into the paddocks and again when they are brought in at night. The brood mares are fed on stud cubes and milk pellets. Each horse has a separate stable. In their stable they have an infrared lamp to keep the mares warm. This is necessary as in January and February when the brood mares foal it is very cold. To know when the horses are foaling there is a built-in camera to watch the progress of the birth. When the foals are weaned, they are prepared for the Ascot sales where they are sold and used for racing.
